content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]]name = "Courses"url = "courses/"weight = 50 Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]]name = "Docs"url = "docs/"weight = 50 Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
1. Personal research topics{"x":{"diagram":"
digraph {
 graph [layout=circo]
 
 node [shape = circle,
 fontname = Helvetica,
 style = filled, fontsize=20]
 
a [label = "AM", fillcolor = lightcyan]
b [label = "Cardiology/AF", fillcolor = azure]
c [label = "Ob/gyn", fillcolor = linen]
d [label = "PhD: Pregnancy loss and
long term health", fillcolor = mintcream]
e [label = "Fetal sex
and VTE", fillcolor = honeydew]
f [label = "The Pill and
Autoimmune Disease", fillcolor = ivory]
g [label = "CPA
and benign tumors", fillcolor = snow]
h [label = "CIP and VTE", fillcolor = oldlace]
 a-b-c-d-{e f g h}
}","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}
2. FlowchartsFlowcharts are used extensively in almost all medical research.
{"x":{"diagram":"
digraph {
 graph [layout=circo]
 
 node [shape = circle,
 fontname = Helvetica,
 style = filled]
 
 node [fillcolor = honeydew, fixedsize=TRUE, width=2.5]
a [label = "Flowcharts"]

 node [fillcolor = ivory, fixedsize=TRUE, width=2.5]
b [label = "Inclusion/exlusion criteria"]
c [label = "DAGs"]
d [label = "Qualitative research setup"]
e [label = "Network analysis"]
f [label = "Clinical trial setup"]
g [label = "Explaining physiology"]
 a-{b c d e f g}
}","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 1. Examples of flowcharts in medical research. Circo layout.

3. Why program a figure?UpsidesFigures generated and updated inside your programReproducibilityOutput in chosen format
Open-source
Copy-paste{"x":{"diagram":"
digraph D {
 graph [rankdir=LR]
 node[style=filled]
 subgraph cluster_c1 {
 label = R;
 Data-Analysis-Report;
 }
} 
","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 2. Possible self-documenting work-flow
DownsidesSteeper learning curve than “point-and-click”
Time-consuming for special circumstanceshttps://www.researchgate.net/figure/Making-sense-of-GWAS-an-overview-Shown-is-a-flow-chart-of-analytical-and-experimental_fig1_288832409

4. Using the DiagrammeR packageSyntaxBased on DOT programming language and graphViz engine for rendering. Almost 30 years old, but still updated. DiagrammeR package allows DOT programming and graphViz rendering inside R environment.
Central to using the DiagrammeR package in R is the grViz() statement. This function expects 3 statements:
1. graph statement (optional)
2. node statement
3. edge statement
Simple example#install.packages("DiagrammeR")library(DiagrammeR)grViz("digraph{# graph statementgraph [layout = dot]#node statementnode [shape = box, fixedsize=true, style=filled, fillcolor=honeydew, fontname=helvetica]A; B; C; D; E; F; G#edge statementA->{B C D E F G}}"){"x":{"diagram":"
 digraph{
 
 # graph statement
 graph [layout = dot]
 
 #node statement
 node [shape = box, fixedsize=true, style=filled, fillcolor=honeydew, fontname=helvetica]
 A; B; C; D; E; F; G
 
 #edge statement
 A-{B C D E F G}
 }
","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 3. Simple example. DOT layout.
LayoutFor now, focus on two types1. dot (hierarchical)
2. circo (circular)More exist
Integration with existing prgorammingIn R integration is done using footnotes and @@ operator.
Attributeshttps://rich-iannone.github.io/DiagrammeR/graphviz_and_mermaid.html
Examplea <- LETTERSgrViz(diagram = "digraph{# graph statementgraph [layout=circo]# node statementsnode[shape=circle, style=filled, fillcolor=honeydew]A [label = '@@1-1']B [label = '@@1-2']C [label = '@@1-3']D [label = '@@1-4']E [label = '@@1-5']F [label = '@@1-6']G [label = '@@1-7']node[shape=box, style=filled, fillcolor=lightblue]H [label = '@@1-8']I [label = '@@1-9']J [label = '@@1-10']K [label = '@@1-11']L [label = '@@1-12']M [label = '@@1-13']N [label = '@@1-14']# edge statements{A B C}->{H I J K N} G->{L M N}}[1]: LETTERS[1:14]"){"x":{"diagram":"
 digraph{
 
 # graph statement
 graph [layout=circo]
 
 # node statements
 node[shape=circle, style=filled, fillcolor=honeydew]
 A [label = "A"]
 B [label = "B"]
 C [label = "C"]
 D [label = "D"]
 E [label = "E"]
 F [label = "F"]
 G [label = "G"]
 
 node[shape=box, style=filled, fillcolor=lightblue]
 H [label = "H"]
 I [label = "I"]
 J [label = "J"]
 K [label = "K"]
 L [label = "L"]
 M [label = "M"]
 N [label = "N"]

 # edge statements
 {A B C}-{H I J K N} 
 G-{L M N}

 }","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}
5. Flowchart example# Body of nodes in flowchart. 
 indicates new lineset.seed(1)cohort <- data.frame("pnr"=1:1000, "pre_cancer"=rbinom(1000, 1, 0.01), "emigration"=rbinom(1000, 1, 0.01), "group"=rbinom(1000, 3, 0.3))flow <- data.frame("tekst"=c("Patients between 1995-2020","Exluded due to previous cancer
","Exluded due to emigration
","Total exluded","Total included in study","Group 0","Group 1","Group 2","Group 3"))flow$n[1] <- nrow(cohort)flow$n[2] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$pre_cancer==1,])flow$n[3] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$emigration==1,])flow$n[4] <- flow$n[2] + flow$n[3]cohort <- cohort[cohort$pre_cancer==0 & cohort$emigration==0,]flow$n[5] <- nrow(cohort)flow$n[6] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==0,])flow$n[7] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==1,])flow$n[8] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==2,])flow$n[9] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==3,])# Putting n and text in one cell with correct formating and alignmentflow$ntekst <- with(flow, paste0("n = ", format(n, big.mark=",", trim=TRUE), " ",tekst))# Putting exclusion into one cellexclusions <- with(flow, paste0(ntekst[2], ntekst[3], ntekst[4]))# Removing exclusions from flow data.frameflow <- flow[c(1,5:9),]flowchart <- grViz(diagram="digraph{graph[layout=dot, fontsize=12]#body text for all except exclusionsnode [shape=box, fixedsize=false, fontname=helvetica]A [label = '@@1-1']B [label = '@@1-2']G0 [label = '@@1-3']G1 [label = '@@1-4']G2 [label = '@@1-5']G3 [label = '@@1-6']#body text for exlusionsnode [shape=box, fixedsize=false, fontname=helvetica]Excl [label = '@@2']#Empty cells for invisible pointsnode [style=invis, width=0, height=0]P1 [label ='']P2 [label ='']#edge statements in up/down directionA->P1 [arrowhead = none]P1->ExclP1->BB->P2 [arrowhead = none]P2->{G0 G1 G2 G3}#edge statement for vertical edge to exclusionssubgraph{rank=same; P1; Excl;}}[1]: flow$ntekst[1:6][2]: exclusions")flowchart{"x":{"diagram":"
 digraph{
 graph[layout=dot, fontsize=12]
 
 #body text for all except exclusions
 node [shape=box, fixedsize=false, fontname=helvetica]
 A [label = "n = 1,000 Patients between 1995-2020"]
 B [label = "n = 978 Total included in study"]
 G0 [label = "n = 351 Group 0"]
 G1 [label = "n = 417 Group 1"]
 G2 [label = "n = 183 Group 2"]
 G3 [label = "n = 27 Group 3"]

 #body text for exlusions
 node [shape=box, fixedsize=false, fontname=helvetica]
 Excl [label = "n = 14 Exluded due to previous cancer
n = 8 Exluded due to emigration
n = 22 Total exluded"]

 #Empty cells for invisible points
 node [style=invis, width=0, height=0]
 P1 [label =""]
 P2 [label =""]

 #edge statements in up/down direction
 A-P1 [arrowhead = none]
 P1-Excl
 P1-B
 B-P2 [arrowhead = none]
 P2-{G0 G1 G2 G3}
 
 #edge statement for vertical edge to exclusions
 subgraph{
 rank=same; P1; Excl;
 }
 }","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 4. Example flow chart. Dot layout.

6. Exportinglibrary(htmltools)library(DiagrammeRsvg)library(rsvg)#Personal preferred export types: svg for vector based, png for picture based graphics. Each file type has pros and cons. Don't mind warning message <unknown>:1753848: Invalid asm.js: Function definition doesn't match use# svgflowchart %>%export_svg %>% charToRaw %>% rsvg_svg("graph.svg")# png flowchart %>%export_svg %>% charToRaw %>% rsvg_png("graph.png")# pdfflowchart %>%export_svg %>% charToRaw %>% rsvg_pdf("graph.pdf")# htmlsave_html(HTML(export_svg(flowchart)), file = "graph.html")Extended readinghttps://rich-iannone.github.io/DiagrammeR/graphviz_and_mermaid.html
https://graphviz.org
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/DiagrammeR/index.html
https://renenyffenegger.ch/notes/tools/Graphviz/examples/index
title: Flowcharts using DOT/graphViz/Diagrammer

content:
The aim of this site is to
provide up-to-date scientifically based information in the specialty of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, within our expert fields.
offer access to scientific information in a form readable for also non-doctors
express our opinion on actual issues – called “editorials”
give access to presentations made by our staffThe information is indexed according to the index below
ScopeThe access to rapid and often free information within any field has expanded rapidly by time. During the latest decade, however, in many areas, ideological issues increasingly influence the selection of information presented, with the consequence that even professionals sometimes apparently live in “different worlds”.
We all know that nobody can be 100% objective. Our way strive for objectivity is based on three principles: No commercials on this site. None of us are engaged in boards of pharmaceutical companies, and none of us have shares in industry. This is of course no guaranty of objectivity, like people who have such engagements may be fully objective. But nevertheless.We also attempt to go beyond apparently conflicting results in different studies on the same topic, and to do better than just to declare: We can draw no conclusion, as different studies emerge with different results. Our experience tell us, at usually, one might explain the apparently different results. Good studies generally provide more reliable results than poor studies.
In order to make the information on this site relevant for clinically working people, all who are presenting information on this site are clinically working colleagues (part-time or fulltime).Finally, we encourage colleagues who want to share useful information and at the same time fulfill our principles outlined, to send us such information. We have full right to refuse such an upload, but will be happy to do so, if we find the information useful.
So, please enjoy.
INDEXThe information is indexed according to the following headlines:
Short- and long-term health issues with use of hormonal contraceptionUse of hormonal contraception in Denmark / Scandinavia
Hormonal contraception and risk of venous thrombosis
Hormonal contraception and risk of arterial thrombosis
Hormonal contraception and risk of breast cancer risk
Hormonal contraception and risk of ovarian cancer
Hormonal contraception and risk of endometrial cancer
Hormonal contraception and risk of colo-rectal cancer
Hormonal contraception and risk of depression/suicides
Hormonal contraception; clinical notes
Frequent questions and our answersHormone therapy and cancer riskHow does different types of hormones influence the risk of different female cancersMiscarriagesThe frequency of miscarriages in Denmark through 40 years.
Reproductive prognosis after pregnancy losses
Associations between miscarriages and future health in mothers
Frequent question and our answersInduced abortionMedically and surgically induced abortion in Denmark 2000-2019
Early pregnancy national quality assessment in Denmark (Tigrab.dk)
1st trimester medically induced abortion
2nd trimester medically induced abortionFrequent question and our answersPost-term birth-induction and stillbirth risk

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry"if porridge == "blueberry":print("Eating...")  Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}} Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}}- Only the speaker can read these notes- Press `S` key to view{{% /speaker_note %}} Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}{{< slide class="my-style" >}}  Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1,.reveal section h2,.reveal section h3 {color: navy;}  Questions? Ask
Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides
